utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: What was the crime? What was the crime that you're talking about?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, listen, I mean, I think you -- some would argue that in volume two of the Mueller report, there's seven instances where they feel as though -- the Dems -- some Democrats feel as though, he obstructed justice. But, once again, their job is to convince the -- they have to convince --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, it doesn't bother them that the attorney general of the United States and even the investigation itself couldn't decide that. They're going to decide that.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, Robert Mueller in his -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: Do they call it the cover-up, Martha, that's the thing.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, Robert Mueller in his testimony was very clear that he thinks the president -- in the conversation way in his questioning with Ted Lieu, yes, he walked that back. But when he walked through the steps of obstruction of justice, he said, "Yes, I would try this person for obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes, we got to leave -- we got to leave it there.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Once again, this is about the court of public opinion.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well, apparently.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: Jerry Nadler need to take the (INAUDIBLE). if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: OK, and it is not a small addendum there that he walked it back because that -- that's a big -- that's a big deal. And you'd walk back. So, we got to leave it there guys and I will see you soon. Thank you very much. Good to see you both tonight.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, the Supreme Court has just delivered a huge win to President Trump on the border wall. The details coming up. He's going to be a happy man tonight. Plus, Democrats adopt a new talking point after their Mueller disappointment. They questioned the patriotism of President Trump and his allies. They say they are the ones who are on the side of patriotism. Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani, joins me exclusively next.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF., HOUSE SPEAKER
utterances.sentences: The facts and the law. That's what matters. Not politics, not partisanship, just patriotism. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So President Trump tonight has scored a major legal win on his border wall. The Supreme Court just moments ago in a 5-4 division said that the administration can tap into Pentagon funds in order to build sections of a wall along the southern border. $2.5 billion that was frozen is now accessible after two groups led by the ACLU sued the Trump administration when he declared an emergency along the border. The President responded moments ago. "Wow! Big victory on the wall. The United States Supreme Court overturns lower court injunction, allowing southern border wall to proceed. Big win for border security and rule of law." Also, this evening, since the Mueller hearing ended with a thud, the talk has turned from crime to the question of patriotism. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: REP. ANDRE CARSON, D-IND.
utterances.sentences: I think it shows an infuriating lack of patriotism from the very people seeking the highest office in the land.

utterances.speaker: REP. ADAM SCHIFF, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: Part of what I found so powerful about his testimony today was not just when he was asked about the law but when he was asked about the ethics, the morality, the lack of patriotism of this conduct. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: REP. JERRY NADLER, D-N.Y.
utterances.sentences: A president who engages in crimes, repeated crimes to cover up these unpatriotic and dictatorial actions, and this cannot go on.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So on the other side of the aisle, the President and his supporters have said that the lack of patriotism is not on their side, it is with those who sought "insurance policy against him just in case he won the election."

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: This was a fake witch-hunt and it should never be allowed to happen to another president again. This was treason, this was high crimes, this was everything as bad a definition as you want to come up with. This should never be allowed to happen to our country again.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So now given the new argument that's being made, the question becomes who gets to claim the mantle of patriotism in America in this battle. Here now exclusively tonight Rudy Giuliani. Mayor, good to see you tonight. Thank you for being here. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: RUDY GIULIANI, LAWYER OF DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: How are you, Martha?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I'm doing well. Thank you so much for coming in. You know, it's interesting when you look at the argument -- because the word patriotism was used over and over and over again ever since Mueller finished talking.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It's become a major theme in the Democrats language.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's not going to -- it's not going to work any better than Mueller work for them. Everyone knows what happened to them the other day. Mueller got knocked out marginally because there's no case. I mean, there's a lot of attacks on Bob and he wasn't smart and he didn't pay attention, maybe -- it may be true. But there's a real problem. You can only go so far in creating a phony case and Bob ultimately does have integrity. He was asleep at the switch, the inmates took over the asylum like Weissmann and did all kinds of horrible things trampling on people's rights which is the uncharacteristic of Bob Mueller, by the way, which always made me wonder is he in charge of this thing. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } And the reality is that the Democrats are now making total clowns out of themselves. It's not about patriotism, it's about do you have any sense of decency. I mean, this is over. They couldn't -- they couldn't find collusion. They couldn't find obstruction in any sensible way. I mean, he didn't obstruct anything. There was no underlying crime. There isn't a seasoned prosecutor in the country that would bring a case like that except laugh at it. So now they're trying to do -- we must have done something wrong or it wasn't presented correctly or if Andrew Weissmann couldn't get three people to lie about Donald Trump, one of them that he put in solitary confinement and I would say came pretty close to torturing, Manafort, put the guy in solitary confinement bring him back nine times, tell him what to say, if he says it he gets out of solitary confinement. That's what we call suborning perjury. If he couldn't do it, believe me, these two guys who are trying -- Nadler and Schiff who were not operating really with the same mental power as Weissmann. Weissmann is much brighter than they are and much more than malicious in some ways. If he couldn't do it, they're not going to do it.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So one of the interesting things that happened in the hearing in the questioning side was that I think a lot of America started to hear things that they had never heard before. We've covered both sides of this story throughout the case of the entire thing that you know, the president's side feels that there was some kind of potentially a setup, Papadopoulos, we've had him on this show. He's talked about what he believes happened to him. But listen to Devin Nunez as he went through this line of questioning that you know, I watched some of the other channels coverage and it was like they've never heard of any of these people. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT MUELLER, FORMER SPECIAL COUNSEL
utterances.sentences: Can you repeat the question? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: REP. DEVIN NUNES, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: Whether or not you interviewed Stephen (INAUDIBLE) who organized the Cambridge --

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: In those areas, I am going to stay away from.

utterances.speaker: NUNES
utterances.sentences: So Downer conveys a rumor he supposedly heard about a conversation between Papadopoulos and Joseph Mifsud. James Comey has publicly called Mifsud a Russian agent yet your report does not refer to Mifsud as a Russian agent.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, literally I heard people saying what? Who was he talking about? What is he talking about? So my question for you is as the president's attorney, what is the next step in terms of shedding more light on what you believe is the other side of “The Story” that that should be pursued here?

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, we're going to find out that Mifsud was operating for a so-called friendly intelligence service, not Russia, that he was given --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: A Western-European British Intelligence. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. And that he was given the information to feed to Papadopoulos which if you had any common sense or a sense of honesty, you figured out -- I mean, I knew that immediately. I've done a lot of counterintelligence investigation so is Mueller. It has all --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But George Papadopoulos said he thought it was --

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: The whole scheme with Papadopoulos has all the earmarks of foreign counterintelligence, dirty trick.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You've got a young guy who just joins the team --

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Not a genius to figure out.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And suddenly people are calling him, reaching out to him and saying you know, we'd like to meet with you in London. We'd like to meet you.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: The guy go down on the campaign and then they bring a beautiful woman in to try to seduce --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: I mean, this is out of a cheap novel. And I can -- I can speculate but can't tell you who I think is doing it but it got to be somebody who's got a real big intelligence background, and somebody who willing to carry on --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Like -- any names come to mind?

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Well, a couple come to mind but I don't want to accuse anybody without having the facts. Let's see -- let's see what happens. Comey is right in the middle of it. I mean, Comey is got to be the center of this investigation. He's probably not where it stops, it probably goes higher, but Comey signed an affidavit that is patently false about Steele. He said on the top of the affidavit verified. Four months later he told the president was unverified. He can't -- it can't be unverified four months later if it's verified four months earlier. So this guy is headed for big trouble. Let's see if he talks and let's see if McCabe talks. And I don't know, Peter Strzok, you think maybe he's a candidate for giving state's evidence? He doesn't look like the strongest character to me.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: We will be watching. Mayor Giuliani, always good to see you. Thank you so much for coming in tonight, sir. We'll see you soon. When we come back, breaking news on Nicholas Sandmann's defamation lawsuit against the Washington Post and this is big, folks. Stick around.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Breaking news tonight on the $250 million defamation lawsuit that was filed by Covington Catholic Student Nicholas Sandmann against the Washington Post to federal judges has just issued a ruling. Chief Breaking News Correspondent Trace Gallagher got THE STORY for us tonight. Trace?

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, CHIEF BREAKING NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: And Martha, the breaking news is that lawsuit has been dismissed. In the lawsuit and in court, attorneys for Nick Sandmann argued that The Washington Post ignore journalistic standards and bullied the teen by "publishing a series of false and defamatory print and online articles which effectively provided a worldwide megaphone to smear a young boy who was in its view and acceptable casualty in their war against the President." But federal judge William Bertelsman appointed by Jimmy Carter dismissed the case saying the accusations were not supported by the plain language of The Washington Post article. The judge went on to say, when it comes to modern libel laws, there are many defenses, even in the case of defamatory statements. Remember, Nick Sandmann was widely vilified after cell phone video clip showed him staring down Native American Nathan Phillips. But the full video clearly shows that Sandmann and his Covington High School classmates were not the instigators. But Judge Bertelsman says, it appears Nathan Phillips felt he was being blocked by the students and his opinion, the judge rolled, "he -- meaning Mr. Phillips, pass those conclusions onto the Post. They have been erroneous, but as discussed above, they are an option protected by the First Amendment and the post is not liable for publishing those opinions." Nick Sandmann's father release this statement about the dismissal. Quoting, "If what was done to Nicholas is not legally actionable, then no one is safe." Sandmann's lawyers also wrote, quote, "The law must protect innocent minors targeted by journalists publishing click-bait sensationalized news." The attorneys are also planning to appeal the decision, lawsuits against CNN and NBC are still pending, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes, that one was far from over, I think. Trace, thank you very much. So, one week after the House passed a bill to mandate $15 per hour minimum wage some members of the squad as they call themselves want to take it a step further. Michigan Congresswoman Rashida Tlaib saying that she is calling for nearly 940 0 percent increase in the federal minimum wage for tipped workers from to $13 an hour to $20, she says, they should get per hour.

utterances.speaker: REP. RASHIDA TLAIB, D-MICH.
utterances.sentences: We can't allow people to be living off tips, you know, relying on tips for wages. It's just not or (Inaudible) they're calling, it's incompetent. It's just not enough to support our families. (Inaudible) $20 an hour.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Here now, Charlie Kirk, founder and president of Turning Point USA and a bestselling author, and Rochelle Ritchie, Democratic strategist and former press secretary for the House Democrats. Great to have both of you with us this evening.

utterances.speaker: ROCHELLE RITCHIE, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: Hi, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Let me start with you, Charlie. What's your response to Rashida Tlaib and her squad cohorts? CHARLIE KIRK, FOUNDER & PRESIDENT, TURNING POINT USA: Sure. Well, the numbers when you actually look at raising the minimum wage it might feel good and sound good but really, we've seen what happened in New York City, 75 percent of restaurants have had to cut hours and cut back staff because of a raise in the minimum wage. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that 3.7 million jobs would be lost if the federal minimum wage went up $15, let alone $20 an hour. Not to mention prices go up. It's the consumer that ends up having to pay more and then it's the middle class and lower-class workers, entry-level positions that get cut when you raise the minimum wage and it's a burden on the middle class and the middle -- lower middle-class workers.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez watch a segment about this on Fox & Friends the other day and then she tweeted this. "I've waited tables and I've interviewed on live TV. Going on TV can be stressful, but restaurant chefs are much, much harder. Most of these Fox News correspondence couldn't last one day in these hard-working jobs they love to mock on television." First of all, I doubt that she was -- that they were mocking the jobs on television and I should point out that this Fox News correspondents spent eight years waiting tables and it is very, very hard work.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I think it's harder than being in Congress, perhaps.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, what it's funny that she said that because I actually when I graduated from college, I was a waitress and then I was a reporter for 12 years. So, I know exactly how it feels. And being a reporter, I will tell you is much harder than being a waitress, not to say that it's not a hard job. But you know, Charlie is absolutely right. You have to look at the numbers. And I feel, you know the saying when they say give a person an edge and then are going to a mile? I see that that's kind what's happening now that we have this House bill passing for $15. And yes, there is an argument there that making to $13 an hour for some waitresses or servers actually does put them their poverty rate at 19 percent compared to those who have a standard minimum wage. Where it's 11 percent --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes, but I thought the rule is if you don't get up to minimum wage with your tips, then they have to get you to minimum wage. That's the way it was when I was a waitress.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. They're not getting to $13 an hour. They're getting --

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: They're getting more.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- minimum wage an hour. Yes.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: And then also the thing about this.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Not the very least.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: The IRS actually says that 40 percent of tips go unreported, so we really don't know what the numbers are. I think we have to slow down and see how does -- how if $15 actually gets through the Senate or whatever. If the $15 does, how does that impact us and do we have room to do more?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know, I wonder how hard -- you know, I mean, some members of Congress work very hard and like any job in America, you know, but they get an enormous amount of time off, they make $174,000 a year and they work in Washington, 200 days a year. So, she, yes, is definitely in better shape than she was bar tendering --

utterances.speaker: KIRK
utterances.sentences: Not to mention the health benefits.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Gets about 26,000.

utterances.speaker: KIRK
utterances.sentences: They are having a very nice vacation right now. They say they are visiting constituents but it seems as if they always end up in Aspen, Colorado and other nice parts of the country. The final thing, those wages are actually finally going up in this country for the first time in 12 years, thanks to the booming economy that President Trump has been able to oversee with tax cuts and regulation cuts. The very same things that they are advocating for with these wage hikes, we're actually seeing in the real economic data.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, that's the question that is raise by this. Do you eliminate jobs, Rochelle, when you force companies to raise the minimum wage, and it seems like the numbers back that up? And really, the whole idea with minimum wage is that it's just -- it's for a short time. Right?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, you want to -- that's your first job. And then you want to make more money actually.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, you go from making 20, then you want to make 30 then you want to make 40. I mean, it just continuously grows. But I read an interesting article by a gentleman name Frank Helany (Ph). He talked about how when he went to a Seattle restaurant where they actually have this $15 for every employee that on his bill, it was a 20 percent service charge because the restaurant does not make enough money to pay that much per hour. So, what's going to end up happening the business, the restaurant is going to go out of business. And I live here in New York City, I'm already paying $15 for a glass of wine when I can go get a botte for --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes, I hear you. And I don't like the mandatory tip. I think it should be like good service.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You should get a bigger tip.

utterances.speaker: KIRK
utterances.sentences: You should earn it.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That's what always motivated me.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: We got to go. Actress Alyssa Milano attacks Dana Loesch saying that she can't support the death penalty and be pro-life. Dana responds when we come back.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, an update to a story that we brought last night about the federal government now reinstating the death penalty for the first time in nearly two decades. The decision has gotten a lot of attention of course from everyone from politicians and activists, even actresses like anti- Kavanagh crusader Alyssa Milano who tweeted this. "Your administration just reinstated the death penalty and scheduled five executions of actual people. You've lost the right to pull your pro-life -- you can see what's under there -- with me." She says. That getting the attention of Dana Loesch who responded with this. "One of these actual people, she responded, sexually molested and tortured his 2- year-old daughter to death. Another slit a 9-year-old throat after killing her grandma. Another raped and dismembered a 16-year-old before beating an elderly woman with polio to death. These criminals, she writes, are actual animals." Dana Loesch joins me now. She's nationally syndicated talk show host. of course, Dana, good to see you tonight. Thanks for coming back. You know, this definitely ignites --

utterances.speaker: DANA LOESCH, SYNDICATED TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.sentences: Good to see you, Martha. Thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- controversy because a lot of people who are pro-life are against the death penalty. You know, so she brings up what she sees as a discrepancy here in the argument. What do you say?

utterances.speaker: LOESCH
utterances.sentences: I would never compare an innocent baby to that of an adult criminal who decides that they are going to, of their own volition, commit something so atrocious that there's no going back from that. You know, I understand the concerns that people have about the death penalty. But at the same time, people need to realize that there is a reason why this punishment, this penalty, was created. It's not done so out of vengeance. It's actually done so to honor the dignity of life that was lost. And I just, I can't compare innocent children to adults who willfully commit such heinous criminal actions and I think that's the big -- that's the big difference for me, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know, obviously everybody has their own feelings about this. This is a very sensitive issue, but clearly, you know, the actions of these five people are the most heinous, horrific crimes that you can imagine. And if anybody deserves the death penalty, it seems that obviously there is very good reason that they are on the list. I want to put up on the screen some other people who are on death row. Some of these names I think people will recognize. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev for his role in the 2015 Boston marathon bombing, white supremacist Dylann Roof, 2017 in the Charleston Church shooting he killed nine people, and Gary Lee Samson who was sentenced to death the second time in 2017 for carjacking murderers. But you know, there is an issue that, you know, for some time, Dana, this was not on the table, we weren't doing federal executions in this country. A lot of Americans are against it. Pope Francis has said that he'd like to see, you know, a global end to the death penalty, that he thinks that it's an inhumane. And it goes back to the question of whether or not is it -- you know, do people human beings have the right to take life, whether it's before birth or at any point during life or is that decision just left up to God?

utterances.speaker: LOESCH
utterances.sentences: Well, I actually think God has spoken about it. I mean, I don't want to bible up with all due respect to the pope, and Romans 13 discusses it. It's also discussed it Genesis, as well. And we could stay on that for a bit. But, biblically, it's been supported. I mean, I looked back at the Eid that that was given to Noah. But in terms of the inhumanity or the lack of humanity for the death penalty, I think it's inhumane what these murderers do to innocent victims.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: No argument there.

utterances.speaker: LOESCH
utterances.sentences: And I think that people tend to forget that sometimes in this whole discussion. A dignity -- dignity of life has been lost in these horrific murders.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LOESCH
utterances.sentences: And you know, those examples that you gave, Martha, from the tweet that I had, that wasn't even the full body count. Those were horrifically, those were just some of the victims that these men had -- the lives that these men had taken.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Let me ask you before I let you go. You know, there is something incongruous about being against -- being in favor of abortion and against the death penalty, though. What about that argument?

utterances.speaker: LOESCH
utterances.sentences: Yes. In favor of abortion and against the death penalty is odd to be because you're condemning one life to death for doing nothing but simply existing, and yet, you are wanting to exonerate another life. That doesn't -- that to me is not close and pathetic. That doesn't make any sense to me.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LOESCH
utterances.sentences: But I hope that people, and one quick note, Martha, I understand that there is corruption in the system. We need to remove the corruption not the justice, and I think we should support checks and balances like the innocence project.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Dana Loesch, always good to see you. Thank you very much for being here tonight.

utterances.speaker: LOESCH
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You bet. Coming up next, so does Tom Brady deserve to be dad shamed after this. Ladies' night coming up next.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So earlier this week, we told you about the New Yorker's Jane Mayer who wrote a hit piece on Brett Kavanaugh last year during the whole Kavanaugh confirmation process. She really in that piece used hearsay, something somebody remembered someone telling them as evidence in the Judge Kavanaugh piece, but now she wrote a lengthy piece in the New Yorker about Al Franken, saying that he had railroaded in the main woman accusing him was not credible. Now the ladies at The View were talking about this collision course between people's politics and Me Too. Watch.

utterances.speaker: MEGHAN MCCAIN, CO-HOST, ABC
utterances.sentences: It's very tricky. And I want you to go back in time and remember, it would be very uncomfortable for Democrats if Al Franken was sitting there questioning Brett Kavanaugh at the same time. I don't think that Me Too and sexual assault should be about which party are you voting in the general election.

utterances.speaker: JOY BEHAR, CO-HOST, ABC
utterances.sentences: Well, according to him, those allegations were part of his personality, the way Biden has been able to get out of those accusations in a similar way.

utterances.speaker: MCCAIN
utterances.sentences: But I wouldn't compare his allegations to Biden.

utterances.speaker: BEHAR
utterances.sentences: Well, they disappeared the minute he resigned.

utterances.speaker: MCCAIN
utterances.sentences: Because I also know pictures of Joe Biden putting his hands on a woman's breast that I'm aware of.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Here now for our own ladies' night, Lisa Boothe, Carley Shimkus, and Jessica Tarlov. Ladies, welcome. Good to have you here. So, you know, that becomes the issue when suddenly Jane Mayer is defending Al Franken after she thrashed Brett Kavanaugh on the thinnest thread of someone telling her something that they remembered happening in the dorm although they weren't there, it just raises the question of whether or not, you know, sort of cheering for one team and not another and not applying the same standard across the board.

utterances.speaker: JESSICA TARLOV, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: I think it's really complicated. As far as the main accuser against Brett Kavanaugh, Dr. Christine Blasey Ford, I happen to believe her. I think that she is telling the truth about what happened. I think there are a lot of people who do believe her and might have either decided he should still be confirmed saying it happened when you're 15 years old. It doesn't matter anymore. Or we are past the statute of limitations.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. But just to remind everybody --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: The Jane Mayer piece wasn't even talking about Christine Blasey Ford.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No. I know. That's why I wanted to draw the distinction.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It is about him not like -- because exposing himself and pushing himself --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Right. When he was psychology --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- in front of --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I just wanted to draw the distinction that that is -- that is the Brett Kavanaugh accuser that I believe in this. And I think Jane Mayer did get herself into a tricky situation. Kirsten Gillibrand actually came to work where I work at Bustle and spoke to us this week the day THE STORY came out and she defended her decision to push for Al Franken to resign. Where she said, you can talk about Leeann Tweeden (Ph) and I think that's a bit of a tenuous story. But she said there were seven or eight, I think it was other women who would also say that Al Franken had made them uncomfortable or touch them inappropriately. And you have to take the entire body of work there. So, you can't be partisan and you do have to take the totality of the story.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. But, you know, politically Kirsten Gillibrand if she starts backing down on anything Me Too related --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Of course, yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- she's going to be in a very tough spot.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't think either of the three accusers of Brett Kavanaugh are credible for my opinion, considering the fact they have zero corroborating evidence and even the witnesses that Christine Ford named said that contradicted what she said.

utterances.speaker: CARLEY SHIMKUS, REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Well, yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: And even one said that she had felt forced by Christine Ford and her friends to change her story. But regarding Jane Mayer, she had tweeted out and saying that almost nothing his main accuser, talking about Al Franken, said checks out. Well, guess what. Neither did her story about Deborah Ramirez, the New York Times who said that they try to pursue the story, interviewed several dozen people and couldn't find anyone to establish this event had happened. That's basically the same story for all three women. NNC has sat on information that would have been beneficial to Brett Kavanaugh and said sat on it until after he was confirmed. So, if anything, if you look at what happened to Brett Kavanaugh, it was an orchestrated smear by the media and that's exactly what the New Yorker piece was for Brett Kavanaugh. It was a smear, and the article about Al Franken is a defense of him.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: And so, it's a case study of media bias.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, we're talking about people's lives, you've got to be careful and you have to make sure that you have your evidence as down cold as you possibly play, Carley.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Yes. And the Franken situation is an example of the frenzy that took place in the immediate aftermath of the Me Too movement where due process completely went out the window. And Democrats put pressure on Franken to resign not because of their moral compass but because it worked for them politically. They came out as a party that says we are going to believe all the women and they couldn't say that with Franken still in office. So, I know that a lot of people have issues with this Mayer piece, but I'm glad that I know that Democrats now feel bad about what they did to Franken because he didn't have a chance to defend himself.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: It was his choice. We need to remember that. He could have gone before and after --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well, he said he regrets it. I mean, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: After three dozen Democrats came and put pressure on him.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: It would have been his choice --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Mayer had told L Magazine later that it was important to establish in a pattern of behavior. So, if you want to look at the motivating factor behind the Brett Kavanaugh piece, that was it. Not because Deborah Ramirez's story was credible, because clearly, it was not. Even Deborah Ramirez said that she was drunk and she didn't remember most parts of the - -

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: There's a lot that goes on. I know it (Inaudible) her part but a lot goes on and happened when people are intoxicated.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: There's nothing credible to her story.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But you know what, I think that were people who got swept up in the early stages of Me Too who probably did not deserve to be there. Is that a statement that you would agree with?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I would absolutely agree with that.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That there are some people who got to that point.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And their careers are ruined, and you know, now I think due process is getting a lot more attention. I hope that's the way defendant -- because every case, no matter what it is, if you rob someone's house, or if you're in a -- everybody deserves due process in America no matter what the charges are. Even Tom Brady deserves it. So, let's give it to him.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Here he is on vacation. I think in Costa Rica with his family. And just watch this.

utterances.speaker: TOM BRADY, FOOTBALL PLAYER
utterances.sentences: One, two, three, go.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: My gosh. I mean, I watch that three times on my phone when it first came out and every time my heart just kind of stops.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: See you can --

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I know.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: You can tell that I'm not a mom yet because I look at that, I'm like, that looks like fun what was there.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It's very fun. And you know, I mean, I'm a big Tom Brady fan so I'm thinking there's way he's letting go of Vivian's hand. There's just no way. She's going to be safely carried into that water.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Yes. By the way that's quarterback in history.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Think all the people -- but all the people that have been shaving him surely there's been a point in time if you a parent that you've been negligent to some degree.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Or something has happened under your watch that potentially put your child in harm, so I just don't -- I find social media so aggravating - -

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: -- when people go on and sort of shamed the way that someone's parents.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: You didn't get that -- it's like dog shaming.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: My gosh. Everybody is the perfect, right?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Everyone else. All these keyboard warriors who were like treating Tom Brady like he doesn't have great judgment.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, like you said, he's doing fine in the decision-making department.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Well, also --

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: And she was OK he wouldn't have posted it on social media if she got hurt.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No, obviously not.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Everything is fine.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: People do that. I'm sure he didn't find like the only little waterfall --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: -- where he certainly got to throw his child off of.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I don't even have Instagram but I have gone on it just to kind of fun girl over the Brady-Bundchen life, and they do --

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.sentences: You got to get you some Instagram.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I don't want. It's scary.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right. We got to leave it there. All right. Thanks, ladies. More with “The Story” after this. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That is “The Story” of Friday, July 26, 2019. But as always, “The Story” goes on. We'll see you back here on Monday night at 7. Have a great weekend, everybody.
